success_stories.description: From small discussion group to major support network. Terms like 'ALS' and 'MND' now recognized.

success_stories.achievement: First ALS Genetic Study in India
success_stories.description: 62+ patients in initial batch. Published research acknowledging ALSCAS. Building national genetic database.
First institutional collaboration. Historic awareness event (June 2025). Commitment for ALS clinic. Director-level support.
Target ALS partnership. ProjectMinE collaboration. International Alliance for ALS/MND membership. Featured in global ALS community.
AIIMS tasked to draft rare disease funding package. ALSCAS input included. Economic impact study submitted.
October 2025: First major study published. Indian ALS genetic data now in scientific literature. ALSCAS acknowledged as contributor.

immediate_1_2_years.description: Multi-disciplinary care, standardized treatment protocols, training hub for other hospitals

immediate_1_2_years.timeline: November 2025 batch results expected by February 2026
immediate_1_2_years.benefits: Access to gene-specific treatments if positive, family genetic counseling

immediate_1_2_years.target: Possibly for FUS or SOD1 mutations
immediate_1_2_years.significance: Would be first ALS clinical trial in India

medium_term_2_5_years.description: AIIMS and NIMHANS as designated sites. Target ALS partnership bearing fruit. Access to global drug trials. Indian patients eligible for experimental treatments.
Comprehensive database of all Indian ALS patients. Genetic data integrated. Disease progression tracking. Research resource for drug companies.
SPG302 trials in India. New gene-specific therapies. Combination treatments. Symptomatic management drugs.
Government recognition of ALS as covered condition. Private insurance including genetic disorders. Financial support for equipment/care.

long_term_5_10_years.description: Discovery of South Asian genetic factors. Understanding younger age of onset in India. Protective genes in slower-progressing cases. Environmental factors unique to India.
CRISPR-based treatments. Gene silencing therapies (like Tofersen but for more genes). Indigenous development of gene therapies. Affordable access through government programs.
Following UK model (20+ MND centers). Major cities: Delhi, Mumbai, Bangalore, Chennai, Kolkata. Standardized care protocols. Telemedicine connections.
Treatments that stop progression. Reversal of symptoms (like NU-9 promises). Prevention for familial cases. Precision medicine based on genetic profile.

current_limitations: No active clinical trials in India (NIMHANS confirmed not participating in outside trials - Nov 2025)
AIIMS not yet running ALS-specific trials
Treatment access barriers - most experimental drugs not available in India
realistic_expectations: Genetic testing will provide results and contribute to research
May get peace of mind if negative for mutations
Even if positive, treatment may not be available/affordable immediately
Clinical trials 2-3 years away minimum with strict eligibility criteria
important_notes.bottom_line: India's ALS community is building the foundation for future breakthroughs, one patient, one test, one collaboration at a time. Cure not imminent (5-10 year horizon more realistic). Current focus: Understanding disease, preparing for trials. Participation in research helps future generations even if not current patients.
